paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.sub_class: A24 Accelerators and Storage Rings, Other
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: A Novel Compact High Rep-Rate Gamma Ray Source Based on Strongly Tapered Undulator Interactions
paper.abstract: Recent experimental efforts have shown strongly tapered undulator interactions to be the most efficient means for exchanging energy between relativistic electron beams and electro-magnetic fields. The Rubicon Inverse Free Electron Laser (IFEL) accelerator demonstrated up to 100 MeV/m acceleration gradients, producing high quality mono-energetic beams. In separate experiments, it was also shown that this acceleration could occur at high rep-rates, and the accelerated beams could be used to produce X-rays through Inverse Compton Scattering (ICS). The Nocibur experiment demonstrated the reverse process, converting 30% of the energy in a relativistic electron beam to coherent radiation. Combining these concepts, we present here a novel scheme where a laser, re-circulated in an optical cavity drives an IFEL interaction, accelerating a 200 MeV beam up to 1 GeV, at which point an ICS interaction can be used to produce gamma rays. This is followed by a Nocibur-like interaction, decelerating the beam below it's initial energy, replenishing the laser energy absorbed in the acceleration stage as well as compensating for cavity losses.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Two Orbit Operation at Bessy II - During a User Test Week
paper.abstract: Operating a storage ring close to a horizontal resonance and manipulating the transverse non-linear beam dynamics can generate stable Transverse Resonance Island Buckets (TRIBs), which give a 2nd stable orbit in the ring. Both orbits can be populated with different electron bunch filling patterns and provide two different radiation sources to the user community. Such a machine setting has been established at BESSY II and was tested under realistic user conditions in a first 'TRIBs/Two Orbit User Test Week' in February 2018. Results and user feedback will be discussed in this contribution.

abstract_log.comments: Dear author, thank you for your submission. Editor found a number of formatting issues. The reference section is outstanding but differs slightly from the JACoW standard. Therefore the entries were modified to allow the requested output # TC06 Text formatting: wrong quotation marks: closing instead of opening e.q. 'standard' # TC06 Reference formatting: editor changed \begin{thebibliography}{9} to {99} because there are 16 references and the alignment was wrong # TC06 Reference formatting: titles are typeset in curly quotation marks # TC09 Figure reference formatting incorrect [at begin of sentence "Figure" may not be abbreviated to "Fig." (in principle at begin of a sentence NO word is abbreviated)] # TC12 Unit formatting: units are printed in roman (upright) fonts (IUPAC rule of 1999), therefore they have to appear outside of math mode or included in \text{}/\mathrm{}: As "$\mathrm{\mu$}" doesn't work on a font which only contains a italic µ use \textmu or the \SI macro with "\micro" instead Please log into your SPMS account, download the PDF file and check the paper for the changes made (and look for editor introduced errors) and when you agree with the changes put it to GREEN via the offered link otherwise reject the changes and give a comment please.
Switched to green so paper can go to QA.
Dear Paul, Your two videos have been embedded into the pdf of your talk for inclusion in the proceedings. Best, jan.chrin@psi.ch

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: High-Charge Injector for on-Axis Injection Into A High-Performance Storage Ring Light Source
paper.abstract: Next-generation, high-performance storage ring light sources based on multibend achromat optics will require on-axis injection because of the extremely small dynamic aperture. Injectors will need to supply full-current bunch replacement in the ring with high single-bunch charge for swap-out. For upgrades of existing light sources, such as the Advanced Photon Source Upgrade (APS-U), it is economical to retain the existing injector infrastructure and make appropriate improvements. The challenges to these improvements include achieving high single-bunch charge in the presence of instabilities, beam loading, charge stability and reliability. In this paper, we discuss the rationale for the injector upgrades chosen for APS-U, as well as backup and potential alternate schemes. To date, we have achieved single-bunch charge from the injectors that doubles the original design value, and have a goal to achieve about three times the original design value.
paper.agency: Work supported by U. S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, under Contract No. DE-AC02-06CH11357.

abstract_log.comments: In the pdf file produced via upload, figures 3, 4 and 5 did not appear and neither did the references with the exception of the first two. Retrieved the source file, which was complete. Removed the full stop at the end of the table 1 caption which was the only formatting error discovered. Congratulations on the excellent preparation of the references. Normally this would be a yellow dot since the editor had to open the source file, however it is so well prepared it deserves a green dot immediately.
